column1: Rule 1: Modifiers containing both a carboxylic acid group (-COOH) and an amino group (-NH2) on an aliphatic chain tend to result in a high yield.
column2: Rule 2: Modifiers with a phenyl group substituted with electron-withdrawing groups such as nitro (-NO2) or halogens (e.g., bromine) tend to result in a high yield.
column3: Rule 3: Modifiers with multiple hydroxyl groups (-OH) on a carbon chain, especially in a sugar-like structure, tend to result in a high yield.
column4: Rule 4: Modifiers containing a pyridine ring tend to result in a high yield.
column5: Rule 5: Modifiers with a sulfanyl group (-SH) tend to result in a high yield.
column6: Rule 6: Modifiers with a formyl group (-CHO) on a phenyl ring tend to result in a low yield.
column7: Rule 7: Modifiers with a methoxy group (-OCH3) on an aliphatic chain tend to result in a low yield.
column8: Rule 8: Modifiers with a long aliphatic chain (more than 6 carbons) without any polar or reactive groups tend to result in a low yield.
column9: Rule 9: Modifiers with a trifluoromethyl group (-CF3) tend to result in a low yield.
column10: Rule 10: Modifiers with an indole group tend to result in a high yield.
column11: Rule 11: Modifiers with a benzofuranone group tend to result in a high yield.
column12: Rule 12: Modifiers with a phenyl group substituted with a hydroxyl group (-OH) tend to result in a low yield.
column13: Rule 13: Modifiers with a benzene ring substituted with a methyl group (-CH3) tend to result in a low yield.
column14: Rule 14: Modifiers with a carboxylic acid group (-COOH) on a benzene ring tend to result in a high yield when combined with additional electron-withdrawing groups.
column15: Rule 15: Modifiers with a benzene ring substituted with an amino group (-NH2) tend to result in a high yield.
